response: narrative=Tom Tyler, a 78-year-old male with a disability, was reported missing from his home at 16 Burney Place, Rosyth. Concerns arose after his son couldn't reach him. It was believed that he might have wandered off, possibly disoriented. The search led authorities to various potential locations based on recent interests Tom had expressed. First, attention was directed towards an abandoned boat near 66 Kirkbank Road, Burntisland, where Tom had been seen exploring weeks prior. Concurrently, a tip suggested checking a storm drain on the outskirts of Rosyth, as Tom had previously spoken about nearby hidden tunnels. After searching multiple areas, Tom was eventually found by the police in an underground bunker at 54 Nethergate South, Crail, alive and unharmed, though slightly dehydrated and confused.

narrative=Tom Tyler was last seen leaving his home at 16 Burney Place, Rosyth. Known for a reclusive lifestyle, particularly avoiding contact with close friends, concern grew when Tom missed his daily routine. A colleague noted that Tom had mentioned a personal project in an underground bunker located near an orchard, raising concerns about his well-being. The search intensified around 39-42 Alexander Place, Rosyth, where Tom was known to volunteer at a local pharmacy. His son contacted authorities, and Tom was eventually found unharmed at the underground bunker involved in his personal project. The incident highlighted the importance of monitoring changes in behavioral patterns for elderly individuals, even with a low-risk assessment.
narrative=MP was found in an underground bunker at 30 Selvage Place, Rosyth, KY11 2QG after no contact with friends.

narrative=Tom Tyler was last seen at a medical clinic near 6-9 West Green, Crail, where he had an appointment. He had recently had no contact with close friends, raising concerns. Following the visit, he was believed to have gone towards a nearby sports arena but was not seen there. His daughter, Geraldine Adams, alerted authorities when he failed to return home. A search led to his rescue from a storm drain, where he had accidentally wandered into after leaving the clinic.

narrative=Tom Tyler, a retired administrator known to have a disability, disappeared from his home at 16 Burney Place, Rosyth. He was last seen by a colleague at the 10-16 Wood Place, Rosyth sports arena, where he usually enjoyed attending local matches. Concerns were raised when he failed to return home and did not respond to any calls. A search was launched by the local authorities in cooperation with his son, who helped trace his usual routes. During the search, evidence suggested that Tom may have wandered towards the storm drains near Lammerlaws, Burntisland, KY3 9BS. He was eventually traced by police on Burntisland Road, Kinghorn, exhausted but safe, nearly 3717 minutes after his disappearance.

narrative=Tom Tyler, a 78-year-old resident from Rosyth, was reported missing after he left his home on a visit to Dunnikier Park, Kirkcaldy. Known for his commitment to volunteer work, he often frequented places such as 1 Dick Place and 1 Fidra Avenue. Concerns arose when he failed to contact close friends and did not return to the assisted living facility at 1 Camdean Crescent. Tyler was eventually traced by his family at a location in Dunfermline after a six-day search around sites including 23 Norval Place and 63 Parkside Street.
narrative=MP vanished from a senior center boat trip. Last seen boarding at 66 Kirkbank Road, Burntisland. Julia Brown noticed his absence.
narrative=Tom Tyler was last seen near a boat at 71 King's Crescent, Rosyth. After a conversation with his colleague, Carl Smith, he disappeared, only to be traced days later.
narrative=Tom Tyler was last seen at the sports arena near North Street, Glenrothes, KY7 5LT, after attending a book club with Katie Wood.

narrative=Tom Tyler was last seen leaving a neighborhood cafe at 23 Tod's Green, Crail. Known for his independent nature, Tom occasionally took solitary walks through scenic orchards nearby. On this occasion, however, Tom became disoriented due to his cognitive impairment, contributing to his disappearance. After an exhaustive local search led by his son and concerned colleagues, there were no immediate clues until a passerby reported seeing an elderly man near a storm drain at 43 Findlay Street, Rosyth. Fearing for his wellbeing, emergency services were dispatched. Two days later, Tom was traced by staff to 1 Parkside Square, Rosyth. He had wandered throughout the area, drawn to familiar places but unable to communicate his situation, until he was finally found.

narrative=Tom Tyler was last seen leaving his home on Birch Avenue, Kinghorn, for one of his regular walks. His family, including his daughter Geraldine Adams, grew concerned when he did not return as expected. It was noted that Tom often enjoyed the solitude of the orchard near 12 Fyne Brae, KY11 8XG, a picturesque spot he frequently visited. Given his physical disability, his prolonged absence raised alarm. Authorities coordinated a search and, after meticulous effort, located him at Pitreavie Court, Dunfermline. The low risk assignment was confirmed as he was found safe by the police. Tom had inadvertently wandered off his route, losing track of time during his excursion.

narrative=Tom Tyler was last seen tending the orchard near 15 Woodside Avenue, Rosyth, a location familiar to his daughter, Geraldine Adams. Despite his limited mobility, often relying on a cane, Tom enjoyed spending peaceful hours there, reminiscing about his younger days. Concern arose when he didn't return home, prompting a search by family members and authorities. Reports suggested Tom might have been disoriented and wandered away toward a nearby underground bunker, a place he had once taken shelter in storms. His son, Carl Smith, coordinated with the police, who eventually found Tom safe on a boat docked not far from his home.

narrative=Tom Tyler, who had no contact with close friends, was last noted leaving 10-16 Wood Place, Rosyth. He had mentioned meeting an old colleague on Burntisland Road, Kinghorn, but didn't arrive or inform his daughter.

narrative=Tom Tyler was last seen near a hospital, discussing plans with his daughter, Geraldine Adams. Concern arose when he failed to return home. A search revealed he had accidentally taken shelter in a storm drain, thinking it was a familiar underground bunker.

narrative=Tom Tyler, an elderly gentleman with disabilities, was reported missing from his home at 16 Burney Place, Rosyth. His son contacted authorities after noticing no contact with close friends, which was unusual for Tom. He was last potentially sighted around the 39;41;43 The Temple, Lower Largo, near an orchard where he enjoyed visiting. A colleague mentioned he was seen heading towards a nearby boat. Given Tom's condition, a high-risk alert was issued. Thankfully, he was later found safe at a friend’s house, 7 Pitreavie Court, Dunfermline.
narrative=MP was found in an underground bunker near a synagogue. Colleague noted MP had no contact with close friends.
